unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Candy Colors
question_text: Some years ago Ms. Tracey (a statistics teacher) gave her class bags of a certain type of candy. She had $50$ students in $2$ classes. The candy company claimed that we would find $10\%$ red candies and $20\%$ yellow candies.  Well, Ms. Tracey's students found the opposite percentages in the candies! Do you think that this result is likely due to random variation?  And what comment below explains the yes or no answer the best?

choices.text: Yes. In bags of candy you would always expect some random variation.
Yes. There was no random assignment so we cannot draw any conclusions.
Yes. We do not know if the candies were normally distributed so we cannot make any conclusions.
No.   Fifty bags are a big enough sample to show statistically that the company was wrong.
No. While we might always expect some random variation, the fact that the percentages were reversed is just not likely.
